title: Before 3 November 2020, will federal legislation to provide at least $100 billion in direct financial assistance to state and/or local governments become law?
preds: They ran out the clock pushing the Supreme Court nomination through, which meant they won't have to help anyone.  As a Republican, I more or less constantly lament the fact that the old saw is true:  Democrats help people; Republicans judge people.  (This is of course only a glib restatement of the general difference between progressives and conservatives, but it still causes pangs.)

Updates:
— "Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin delivered a downbeat assessment Friday about his economic stimulus talks with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), saying the speaker had 'dug in' and 'significant differences' remain ... the soonest Congress is likely to act would be in the 'lame duck' session following the election. Lawmakers will be facing a Dec. 11 government shutdown deadline and will have to pass a new spending bill. It’s possible some coronavirus relief measures could be attached." https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/10/23/trump-congress-coronavirus-bailout/
— "Optimism faded on Friday for a pre-election breakthrough on a stimulus measure to stabilize a shaky pandemic-era recovery, as negotiations between leading congressional Democrats and the White House limped past yet another self-imposed milestone with no deal and no resolution in sight ... With only six workdays remaining before Election Day, time has essentially run out for a stimulus deal to be enacted before the final day of balloting, with Ms. Pelosi previously telling reporters that text would need to be completed by the end of this week in order to become law by Nov. 3." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/23/us/politics/congress-trump-stimulus-deal.html Revising downward.

It seems like the COVID relief package that Pelosi and Mnuchin are negotiating has quite a bit of $ for state/local governments — "the package ... includes at least $300 billion for state and local aid." https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/10/22/trump-congress-coronavirus-bailout/ And the two sides seem close to a deal! But Election Day is right around the corner and it does not seem likely that the Senate will vote for any package before then — and that's assuming that the 13 GOP votes are all there. https://twitter.com/JakeSherman/status/1319404100359016448
Looking more like sometime after November 3rd. https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/coronavirus-stimulus-vote-could-come-after-election-day/ar-BB1agxsl

Time is running out.  Trump is only interested in the impact on his election, the Senate hates the size, and the Dem's are waiting until JoeB can approve the real relief.  I'm dropping my probability, again .

The current situation might be evolving toward two main factors for this question:  1) Will a larger federal legislative stimulus package including some state/local aid become law by November 3rd?  Time is growing short for a 'comprehensive' package to be completely worked out and voted upon, by that date. (https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/10/will-mitch-mcconnell-really-blow-up-a-trump-stimulus-deal.html)  2) Will a negotiated deal include at least a 100 billion dollar amount of direct aid to state/local govts.? This reportedly remains a key "sticking point" in negotiations, but aid dollar numbers at times mentioned by both sides via news reports have generally exceeded $100 billion. (https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/21/business/us-economy-coronavirus/stimulus-talks, https://www.cnet.com/personal-finance/senates-skinny-stimulus-package-versus-1-8-trillion-white-house-offer-whats-in-both-bills/) Keeping this question's forecast probability relatively low mainly for its shortening time frame to have something comprehensive agreed upon and enacted into law.  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/21/stimulus-package-is-unlikely-to-get-through-congress-before-the-election-goldman-sachs-says.html

Even if the window of opportunity comes closer now, there seems to be something in the pipeline. "Pelosi, speaking to reporters after a mid-afternoon call with Mnuchin, was asked about prospects for a legislative package by the end of this week. 'I hope so. That’s the plan,' she said.
 'I think it’s very unlikely that a number of that level would make it through the Senate, and I don’t support something of that level,' Senator Mitt Romney told reporters. 'Something far more targeted to the people who really need help, I’d like to see done, and I’d like to see done as quick as possible.'
[...]
'Not every Republican agrees with me, but they will,' he said. Trump added he specifically expects support from McConnell: 'He’ll be on board if something comes.' Pelosi and Mnuchin have been negotiating intermittently since August on a fresh plan to aid Americans slammed by the coronavirus pandemic, which has infected more than 8.2 million people in the country, killed over 220,000 and thrown millions out of work. Any new stimulus would be in addition to $3 trillion in relief that Congress approved earlier this year."
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-usa-congress-idUSKBN27518S It appears Mnuchin wants to keep his post under POTUS 46. The question remains whether or not at least 100bn USD will be included, and whether the law then can be signed before 03 November quite technically. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/20/us/politics/stimulus-deal-mitch-mcconnell-nancy-pelosi.html

Increasing forecast for the moment on today's 'optimistic' statements, though time is running out and (a majority in) the Senate would need to agree to a package that includes the aid specified in this question. https://money.yahoo.com/coronavirus-stimulus-white-house-ups-offer-ahead-of-pelosi-tuesday-deadline-143916866.html

Speaker Pelosi is making another push for a deal with the White House, which seems like a reasonable possibility; however, Senate Republicans are at odds with the White House about the size of a package, so such a deal would face steep odds.

Getting to close to the election, most of congress seems to be focused on getting their judge, and the election (more their own than DT), the Republicans got (or darn near it ) what they want.  Trump has completely abandoned his job, so I see no reason to Republicans to help the country right now.

Pelosi wants $2+ trillion, WH wants no more than $1.8 trillion, and McConnell has unequivocally rejected both numbers. No real upshot (aside for the American public at large) for any group giving up their current position. Trump has already caved and changed his mind enough times to give everyone whiplash. In the past week he has cancelled negotiations, offered a higher number than ever before, and told his main negotiator to make a deal. The GOP are currently prioritizing the SCOTUS vote and likely won't even discuss their 'skinny stimulus' deal until later this week, a deal which is almost certainly going to be roundly rejected in the House even if it does pass the Senate given their recent rejection of Trump's offer. And the House has made clear what it expects in a deal and is unlikely to agree to anything less. All parties involved essentially benefit more from the other's rejecting their offers so they can villainize them then drafting a proposal that works and being seen as the chicken in the negotiations. It's a sad reality, but it's the only one we've got.

"House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) called on the White House to show it was serious about reaching a deal on another coronavirus relief package by moving within 48 hours to reach an agreement on the remaining disputes ... [she] didn’t say what would happen if the deadline wasn’t met ... Earlier Saturday night, a spokeswoman for Mr. Mnuchin said that he had spoken with Mrs. Pelosi and expected to talk to her again on Monday ... even if Mrs. Pelosi and Mr. Mnuchin are able to reach an agreement, many Senate Republicans have said they are opposed to spending close to $2 trillion on another relief package and it is unclear if Mr. Trump would be able to persuade enough of them to support it ... The president has expressed confidence that he would be able to flip reluctant Republicans." https://www.wsj.com/articles/pelosi-pushes-white-house-to-reach-deal-on-coronavirus-relief-11602989800?mod=e2fb

"McConnell announces votes Tuesday and Wednesday on GOP stimulus measures"
https://keyt.com/news/money-and-business/2020/10/17/mcconnell-announces-votes-tuesday-and-wednesday-on-gop-stimulus-measures-2/ "The new bill will include 100 billion to 'make schools safe for kids , McConnell worte"
https://popculture.com/trending/news/second-stimulus-check-mitch-mcconnell-announces-vote-gop-covid-19-relief/ "The bill, according to McConnell, will also include more than $100 billion for schools as well as money for testing, contact tracing, and vaccine development and distribution."
https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/521555-mcconnell-details-500-billion-covid-bill-set-for-wednesday-vote https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/17/senate-to-vote-on-500-billion-gop-coronavirus-stimulus-bill-wednesday.html It is likely the Senate could pass the 500bn USD bill before 03 Nov 2020, but it is unlikely to contain 100bn USD in direct financial assistance to state and/or local governments from my point of view, as required by the question. The Rep Senate feels the pressure, but  they try to put the pressure against Democrats for "withholding the 500bn USD" from American families... However, Dems stress that the bill is insufficient, so this might not catch and backfire instead. Unless a new initiative for a package totaling more than, say 1.5tn USD finds bipartisan support, I guess this question is dead, for the time being.
Stimulus hopes are fading and it's hard to imagine the Senate will approve anything with state funding

From POLITICO's Playbook: "About 20 or so hours ago, Washington’s most eager man -- Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin -- said what we’ve been trying to say for weeks about Covid relief: 'At this point, getting something done before the election and executing on that will be difficult.' ... it seems completely plausible that Covid relief not only will be delayed for now, but could be delayed for several months, and could even slip into late in the first quarter of 2021." https://www.politico.com/newsletters/playbook/2020/10/15/is-covid-relief-ever-going-to-happen-490609 Revising downward from 15% to 7%.

Does not seem to bode well for enacting something before 11/3/20 (link): https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/14/business/us-economy-coronavirus/mnuchin-says-he-does-not-expect-a-stimulus-bill-before-the-election

Increasing slightly due to Trump's statement on the Limbaugh show that he wants more than the Democrat position of $2.4 tril in stimulus. There is no longer a gap in the Democrat/Republican position. I'm just skeptical they could agree on the details that quickly.
Senate Republicans have no incentive to make a deal before the election.
the republicans may make a desparation move to save an electoral wipeout.

(10/9/20:) Latest W.H. stimulus package offer is increased and may include state/local gov't. aid, but McConnell sounds skeptical of quick passage and/or passage as proposed. https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/09/world/covid-coronavirus/white-house-raises-stimulus-offer-in-scramble-to-revive-talks

Probably Not. Politico reports that reaching an agreement and passing a bill would take two weeks minimum. The reason I have remained so high up to this stage is that I was hedging against a surprise from the White House or Democrats on such an important issue and its still possible but definitely becoming less likely. It's going to be one of those things where if it happens it happens suddenly at the last minute. [1] [1] https://www.politico.com/newsletters/playbook/2020/10/09/trump-passed-over-for-nobel-490565

Update from the latest POLITICO Playbook: "President Donald Trump now desperately wants a Covid relief deal, and his White House seems to be trying to make it happen for him ... But Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said today in Kentucky he thinks it is very unlikely something will get done in the next three weeks ... Hill sources tell us that they plan to work through this weekend, all next week and possibly next weekend to get a deal ... The White House's top-line number is $1.8 trillion. The line the GOP can’t cross is $2 trillion. All depends on the details, but this is now significantly higher than the GOP’s previous top line, which was $1.5 trillion ... the administration is aiming for $300 billion in state and local funding." https://www.politico.com/newsletters/playbook-pm/2020/10/09/a-covid-relief-deal-looks-likelier-than-ever-a-law-not-so-much-490569 So basically if a deal is reached and signed into law, it will definitely contain at least $100 billion in aid for state/local governments. I think the likelihood of a deal between congressional Dems and the White House has just gone up significantly — in my view, above 50% — but the key factor is whether the fiscally conservative GOP-controlled senate goes along with this, which I doubt it will (especially since the White House is conceding further ground to congressional Dems and so the final $ amount is going higher).  Revising upward to 15% for now.

Lowering forecast a bit further at this point. Apparently dim prospects (lack of Republican support) for meaningful aid to state/local gov'ts. https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-donald-trump-archive-nancy-pelosi-airlines-81083d06d7709e1ead58205e5ed005c5 https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/08/business/pelosi-trump-stimulus-talks.html

As it seems that the only stimulus bills at all possible at this point are standalone ones, I don't see any chance of state and local governments getting a piece of the action. Even with a slim chance of such a bill leaving the house, it would be DOA in the Senate.
The Senate is all about confirming Amy with all the strength they can muster with little leftover for the crisis at hand.
I am about to get screwed on this question.

A comprehensive stimulus package including direct assistance to state/local govts. may be difficult to enact by 11/3/20.  Republicans are talking more about specific 'standalone' measures and Republican negotiators appear to still be taking overall "direction" from the president. https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/07/business/us-economy-coronavirus/with-stimulus-talks-dead-discussions-for-a-stand-alone-airline-bill-are-renewed
reduced odds. stimulus now from EO or non-legislative funding.

I'm going to bump up my probability because the president is crazy and the republicans are panicking about losing the Senate.  I have NO rational estimate, I'm on gut only.  Not forecasting, just guessing. Sorry.  This is a hairball.

I've flip-flopped to extremes so many times on this question feel like I'm giving a clinic on HOW NOT TO FORECAST.  It's better to make smaller moves and stay closer to the middle on difficult questions -- I'm discovering.  Why is everyone, including me, reacting so much to the news of Trump's latest tweet? He tweeted just Friday, from the hospital, that CONGRESS NEEDS TO AGREE ON STIMULUS! Yet 4 days later, perhaps high on steroids, he tweets he isn't going to let it happen--and we act like it is a fact? My goal going forward on this question is to not go outside the rails of 25 and 75. Hope I can do it.

Seems like stimulus is unlikely to give states money; trump walking away from table. not moving risk to 0 since a big ove down in the stock market likely brings DJT back to the table

Going back up for the week.  I have no insight beyond recent news.  If Pellosi wants adeal the best she gets ks tbe Senates $1trillion offer. R senators are not going to give more. We will see what happens this week.   Maybe back to 0.

Pelosi is optimistic after the coronavirus diagnosis of Trump.  Trump and Pelosi clearly want a stimulus package.  Pelosi because she is worried about the unemployed, and Trump because he expects stimulus to help the economy prior to the election.  However, it is probably too late for that.   Republicans in both houses are worried about a repeat of what happened after they passed TARP in 2008.  That is, a number of long serving conservatives with stellar conservative credentials suddenly were not conservative enough and lost primary elections.   For example,  Mike Lee defeated Bob Bennett in a Utah senate Republican primary in 2010.  Lee argued Bennett was a turn-coat to the conservative cause due to the TARP vote despite his solid conservative credentials.   Nevertheless, the diagnosis of Trump might change a few votes. (The 35 percent was a "mis-click" yet even 25 percent is probably too high.

Revising significantly upward given recent progress: "House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday she anticipates striking a bipartisan economic relief deal with the Trump administration, suggesting that the president’s coronavirus diagnosis could speed up an agreement ... Democrats had sought a $2.2 trillion package, while the White House’s most recent offer was closer to $1.6 trillion. Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin spoke Friday afternoon for 65 minutes and plan to continue their discussions ... In a sign that a deal could be emerging, Mnuchin told at least one Republican senator in a phone call Thursday night that the agreement with Pelosi would include a substantial amount of money for state and local governments." https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/10/02/democrats-white-house-economic-stimulus/

The Republican designed Subprime Crisis and the following "Great Recession" will be inherited to a Democratic president, who then has to "save the world as we know it", and because the merits come late and indebtedness of the U.S. is set to rise anyway, someone else takes all the political capital to earn and the merits in another election.
History repeats, but maybe for a last time before the economic superpower USA has come to a point of no return and to the end of a historic cycle of dominance. Last chance, last round, last order. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/29/democrats-new-stimulus-bill-includes-updated-plan-for-1200-checks.html
Lowering forecast unless/until more optimistic assessments emerge (soon): https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/28/pelosi-mnuchin-final-attempt-covid-talks-422698

Looks like a face saving exercise.    (Dow Jones) -- WASHINGTON -- House Democrats released a $2.2 trillion coronavirus relief package that would restore $600 weekly jobless benefits, a last-ditch effort to revive stalled talks with the White House.
The roughly $2.2 trillion legislation was unveiled Monday evening, with a vote possible later this week, according to multiple Democratic aides. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) told her leadership team she planned to talk to the administration on Monday evening, according to a senior Democratic aide.
Democrats say a large package is needed to support American households and businesses still experiencing the economic impacts of the pandemic. Any legislation would face immediate hurdles in the GOP-led Senate, where many Republicans have resisted a large new round of deficit spending and expressed more confidence that the economy is recovering, after a sharp slump earlier this year.
"We can get this done," Mrs. Pelosi said Monday on MSNBC. "It takes money to crush the virus. It takes money to make the schools safe. It takes money to put money in people's pockets. And, of course, we want some resources to make sure that the state -- that the elections are held."
Many Republican and Democratic lawmakers have pushed for another round of economic stimulus for months, but they have remained far apart on the amount seen as necessary to combat the pandemic that is heading into its ninth month of spreading through the U.S. Lawmakers have been split on the level of weekly unemployment assistance and aid to provide states and cities.
Centrist House Democrats wanted to vote on the legislation before House lawmakers leave Washington this week for the October recess. Mrs. Pelosi initially resisted voting on the bill, pointing out that the House had already passed a roughly $3.5 trillion bill in mid-May and was still trying to negotiate with the administration on a path forward. Previously, deals that have passed both chambers have been negotiated ahead of time.
Though the legislation appears to have little immediate prospect of moving forward in the Senate and becoming law, several of the centrist Democrats pushing for a new bill are facing tough races and want to show that they have tried to secure more aid money for their districts.
But liberal lawmakers are wary of passing a watered-down bill for political purposes that they worry would provide insufficient relief, aides said. Many House Democrats have said that the $3.5 trillion Heroes Act was no longer enough, saying the country's needs have only grown since its passage.
The legislation includes money for restaurants, airlines, child care centers and performance venues hit hard by the pandemic as well as funding for the postal service, which Democrats have said is needed before Election Day. The new bill would include another round of direct checks to Americans, at $1,200 per taxpayer and $500 per dependent. And it would renew the $600 in supplemental unemployment aid that expired in July, according to the text.
The package would also extend the Paycheck Protection Program, which expired on Aug. 8, leaving more than $130 billion in funding unused.
The bill includes $28 billion for a vaccine, including $20 billion for its procurement, $7 billion for its distribution and $1 billion for a public awareness campaign. In addition, $2 billion is set aside to provide more personal protective equipment for all industries significantly affected by the pandemic. It increases federal spending on Medicaid as well.
Also in the package is a measure expanding a tax credit for employee retention that was created in March and has drawn bipartisan support. The program is aimed at keeping workers on payrolls and helping businesses stay afloat by giving employers enough money to cover a percentage of their wages and benefits, plus a credit for fixed expenses like rent.
Mrs. Pelosi will likely have to pass the bill without the support of House Republicans, many of whom are worried about the price of another relief package. Rep. Tom Reed (R., N.Y.), co-chair of the Problem Solvers Caucus, which released a $1.5 trillion proposal earlier this month, said he was concerned House Democrats might be spending too much by going beyond the most urgent priorities.
"It may be too large of a package that goes beyond that immediate need," Mr. Reed said on a call with reporters Monday. But he said he was encouraged that the negotiations continued and that Democrats were offering a new proposal. "If we can get to a narrower package, there's support," he said.

I stand by previous forecasts that this was a lay up for both parties to get passed and neither benefits from no aid being allotted before election day. That made sense then and it continues to make sense from both a political and humanitarian point today. However, I now also realize that politics is never logical when it should be (perhaps I should have known that already). The Senate has moved on to SCOTUS, the House is no longer pushing for any measures, and the President has chosen instead to pretend the pandemic is over and bribe seniors with $200 gift cards for drugs. No one is really even talking about negotiations anymore, so this is basically done.

"House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Sunday said another coronavirus stimulus plan is possible as House Democrats try to forge ahead on a smaller aid package costing about $2.4 trillion, roughly $1 trillion less than their initial proposal but more than what the Trump administration has signaled it will accept ... The chamber could vote on the bill as soon as next week ... Mnuchin signaled earlier this month that the administration would not approve a plan that was larger than $1.5 trillion." [1] Revising downward given that neither side seems to be making any real concessions. Also, at this point, what is the incentive for Pelosi to make a deal? The Dems are now more likely than not to win a majority in the Senate [2], the House majority seems safe [3] (though some individual House members in swing districts may not be — hence their pressure on Pelosi), and passing a new large aid package in a Biden administration would be a good way for Dems to help shore up an economic recovery under Biden. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/27/pelosi-believes-coronavirus-relief-deal-still-possible.html
[2] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/senate/
[3] https://cookpolitical.com/ratings/house-race-ratings

The original 3.4 trillion dollar deal had $900 billion for states and cities from May. Trump has said 1.5, Dems are at 2.2. Let's say even a 1 trillion dollar deal gets done, and the proportion is half (12.5% instead of 25% in May). That still gets you above the $100 billion mark.

Update: "House Speaker Nancy Pelosi abruptly shifted course Thursday and moved to assemble a new coronavirus relief bill to form the basis for renewed talks with the White House, amid mounting pressure from moderates in her caucus and increasingly alarming economic news ... she said the new bill would be around $2.4 trillion ... Republicans dismissed Pelosi’s move as insincere, noting that she was increasing her asking price from $2.2 trillion to $2.4 trillion before talks had even begun ... Partisan disputes that sank earlier negotiations — including Democrats’ demands for generous state and local aid and Republicans’ insistence on liability protections for businesses — also showed little sign of having been resolved." https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/09/24/congress-coronavirus-economic-relief/

Deteriorating individual finances (no job, end of UI payments) and stock market conditions will force both parties to cave on key blocker issues (industry bailouts or mail in ballots) to get a stimulus deal done to enable vote pandering on the homestretch.
Seems less likely now that they'll be arguing over the Supreme Court

Great read: "Two days after the president kept hope alive by saying positive things about the bipartisan House Problem Solvers Caucus’s $1.5 trillion compromise, Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg died ... It will certainly be a huge distraction for various figures involved in stimulus talks, as well as the public ... But with Nancy Pelosi and the White House staff actually conducting the stimulus negotiations (when they are being conducted at all), Politico Playbook speculated that there was a possibility the wild action in the Senate would provide some cover for quiet stimulus talks ... My guess is that if there’s any hope of a stimulus deal being cut before Election Day, it will take some stronger public or private signals from the White House that Trump will ignore his congressional allies and make some big concessions to Democrats to restart talks. And if the federal government actually does shut down, you can probably forget about a stimulus deal anytime soon." https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/09/coronavirus-stimulus-talks-likely-delayed-over-rbg-shutdown.html

Blame game + power game + intensified campaigning.

Weekly update: 
— "House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is urging House Democrats to wait for a better deal on the coronavirus aid package when they return to work Monday ... With talks between the White House and Democrats at a standoff, both parties are looking increasingly likely to spend the final weeks before the election defending the absence of a deal and blaming the other rather than restarting negotiations. Democrats privately hope that prospects of a larger deal will improve after the election." [1]
— "U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on Monday said there still could be a deal with Congress for more federal coronavirus aid, a day after U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi also voiced optimism despite the Senate’s failure to pass an aid bill last week." [2]
— "The HOUSE PROBLEM SOLVERS CAUCUS -- no, still no problems solved quite yet! -- is working on the finishing touches of their Covid relief plan ... It’s going to be somewhere in the neighborhood of $2 trillion and could have north of $500 billion in new state and local aid ... The reasons we’re giving this ink: It’s the only Covid relief action at the moment, it’s caught the White House’s eye and a handful of lawmakers are talking about it. We don’t expect much here." [3] No deal in sight. Lowering by 8% from 33%. [1] https://www.wsj.com/articles/democrats-republicans-point-fingers-over-lack-of-coronavirus-aid-bill-11600086232

Even the Senate's "skinny" stimulus package offers $105 billion for schools nationwide. This money should qualify as state/local assistance. Given that both parties have a pretty clear incentive to pass a bill of some sort. If Republicans starting position is over $100 billion and the Dems are proposing almost 10 times that, it is very difficult to see a bill being passed that doesn't meet this standard, so the question then becomes will a bill be passed by November 3rd? As of today, Republicans are still trying to frame the debate as if Democrats are stalling the discussion. However, Dems proposed a bill months ago and Reps are only recently getting into the fight, so I doubt this argument will play well with voters much longer. More likely, Reps will make a few concessions in order to divert the pressure to Dems, who will either counter with concessions of their own (you know, negotiate) or accept the proposal as is. Not passing some bill has implications that are currently unclear for both parties, so they both have an incentive to get a deal done before the election. I think there will be a deal by October that meets this standard.

No progress in the last few weeks, and it appears both sides see more advantage in NOT reaching a compromise. 4 weeks to go on this question.  I'm dropping to 15% more on hope and statistical variance. Both parties appear eager to make COVID-19 response an election issue by playing to their core constituencies and pointing a finger at the other side.  Aid for state and local governments is currently tightly tied to extending the extra federal unemployment insurance.  The House has passed a bill and can say they tried.  The Senate majority is opposed to this extension because they say it disincentivizes people to work.  I think they all (excluding the President) are willing to perpetuate current positions until after the election.

Republicans thus far have been painting this as an issue of Democrats stalling. However, this argument already holds little to no water and will only continue to diminish as the weeks wear on. Most likely, the Republicans will accept any decent compromise proposed by the Dems in the next month or so to paint it as a win for their party and proof they are reasonable and heroic in a time of crisis. With red states now suffering as much as blue ones, state support and assistance is very much on the table and will likely need to occur to buoy their chances in November. It won't be the $1 billion Democrats initially proposed, but it will likely be more than the $100 million needed for this question.

The Republican-controlled Senate has been stalling on this over the summer. But they know that if they don't do something before the election that it will hurt them badly. So they are waiting to do this sometime in late-September or early October when they believe it might help their chances of winning elections. The public probably won't buy that and will largely vote against them anyway.

Republicans offered $150 billion during negotiations."

The Distinguished Members had a short spurt of activity using federal legislation to assist people.  They were all shagged out by this extraordinary effort and had to go on holiday.  After they return, they will be engaged in trying to get rehired.  This will keep them fully occupied until January at least.   Something like this might get passed by accident, but if it helps the wrong sort of voters it will likely be vetoed by The Leader Of The Free World, assuming he can get his tiny fingers around a pen to accomplish that.  (He doesn't need to work a pen if he doesn't intend to veto; U.S. Constitution Article I, Section 7, down toward the end.)  So slightly better than even odds, but this is probably unrealistic.

Today brings news that the Postal Service story is starting to eclipse the debate on more COVID relief. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has announced plans to pass $25 billion worth of funding ahead of the election while Senate Republicans have countered with a raft of temporary proposals including $10 billion for the USPS. Both of these proposals are almost certainly dead in the water. White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows called money to shore up mail logistics 'unnecessary' and Democrats are unwilling to accept any kind of stop-gap deal that could be hailed as a political victory by the the Trump Administration. Things clearly haven't moved past posturing and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell says we shouldn't expect a deal any time soon. Big update on the state of negotiations: "Crisis negotiations between the White House and top Democrats teetered on the brink of collapse on Friday, as both sides said they remained deeply divided on an economic recovery package and President Trump’s advisers said they would recommend that he bypass Congress and act on his own to provide relief ... another unproductive meeting between the administration officials and Democratic leaders, which ended with no agreement and no additional talks scheduled ... The overall scope and cost of any agreement remains one of the most significant sticking points, along with how much aid should be provided to state and local governments. Republicans have offered $150 billion in new relief, arguing that a significant portion of aid allocated in the $2.2 trillion stimulus law has not yet been spent, while Democrats included nearly $900 billion in their opening proposal." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/07/us/politics/trump-congress-stimulus.html

The Senate GOP included no assistance to state and local government in last week's proposals while the Democrats have passed a bill that would funnel those sources over $1 trillion. In any other year, the GOP could likely out-wait the Democrats and force them to concede on nearly everything, but with an election coming up, and so many vulnerable GOP senators, the clock is ticking on a compromise. It is unlikely all $1 trillion will be approved, but just one-tenth of that granted by the party who was built on a belief in states rights would be enough to clear this bar. While some make the point the Democrats could wait until after the election, if the GOP offers a substantial amount of aid with no response from the Dems, it would not be difficult for the GOP to change the narrative and cast themselves as the party of compromise and empathy, despite their haphazard actions thus far. As such, I think it is in both parties best interests (as well as the White House's) to pass a bill with this level of aid included.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer’s letter to colleagues today indicates that aid to state, local and tribal governments will form part of the negotiations over the next coronavirus relief package. He writes:  ‘Before this state work period, our caucus took to the floor to demand aid to state, local, and tribal governments; coronavirus testing; and supporting our nation’s childcare and education systems.Senate Republicans blocked each of our attempts. Now, Leader McConnell has said that he wants to write the next coronavirus legislation behind the closed doors of his office.’ [1] POLITICO reports that despite their sides being worlds apart McConnell and Pelosi have a shared goal of reaching an agreement within three weeks, well before the November deadline. Of course all this could change from day to day. With recesses in both chambers at the end of August beginning of September, there really isn’t much time left to build consensus before the presidential election. And in some ways it has to be said the Democrats have the most to gain from delaying a deal at this stage. [2] For now though, I think a deal by November for state aid is ‘likely' although the size is difficult to predict until negotiations are underway. This is tough. It's more likely than not simply because of the enormity of the challenge of covid. But, in the CARES Act, there was already over $300 billion allocated for state and local governments. So we are not starting from zero here. I'm not inclined to give a high likelihood because of the fact that the CARES Act was so large and the GOP Senate is not one to go for large spending bills. The House is more likely to pass something because it's led by Democrats and because Reps from districts with state capitals are likely to get pressure from their constituents who might be losing their jobs in city and state government. Senators are less responsive to local issues because their constituencies are statewide. Still, with POTUS changing his tune on a few things recently (like masks) I wouldn't be completely surprised to hear him push the Senate to pass something that could make him look like he's doing more. I just don't think it's a slam dunk because governors, state government and city government workers are not Trump's constituencies.

Not sure what "direct financial assistance means".  Anyway 100 billion dollars for the stages is really a rounding error.  The FED is going to back all the muni bonds. So if the us gov't sends money to the states to help them cover their next bond payment, then the payment will flow to the FED, which is the Us gov't, so the gov't will be paying itself. The pressure to reopen schools is immense.  The pushback against Trump’s approach is immense as well.  He will decide to let the states decide and finance it.  It is the politically expedient way out from his perspective.  It is sound public policy that even McConnel will embrace to avoid losing the Senate.

Only 11 states pay more in federal taxes than they receive back in federal benefits, which means that 39 states are accustomed to receiving "aid". Interestingly, Republican controlled states are some of the largest "takers" of federal benefits. Therefore, it appears quite likely that both houses of Congress will be sufficiently motivated to steer federal aid to state and local governments which will experience severe deficits come September.

Trump wants to re-open the economy, and he has discovered parents can't go back to work if their young kids can't go to school.   The schools depend on state and local government, which have had decreasing income due to the coronavirus.  Some of these states are red states and swing states.   The coronavirus is getting worse right now, and a collapse of state and local governments, which resulted in the closure of public schools and elimination of basic services would not help his re-election. Also, red state voters oppose government spending -- unless they are the ones on the receiving end.   Social security, medicare and Bush's drug benefit program are examples of spending programs that conservatives participate in large number and strongly support.   Therefore, they will want federal money if that will prevent the elimination of things like garbage pickup or higher charges to pay for them.

Both Democrats (in control of the house) and republicans (in control of the senate) are both extremely motivated to pass another stimulus soon. President Trump is has also spoken about releasing a new stimulus bill soon. With both branches motivated to pass legislation quickly, I suspect that the new package will come well before the November 3 deadline. The total amount will most likely be less than the first round based off the current stances of the Senate Majority leader Mitch McConnell and the house Treasury Steve Mnuchin. Republicans are seemingly in favor of limited checks to those who are making less than $40,000. They are also in favor of lowering the amount of Unemployment Insurance from the $600. This will probably limit the total amount of direct financial assistance to under $1 trillion according to early reported estimates. With early estimates seemingly starting at that amount, it is highly likely that the new stimulus package will well exceed the $100 Billion threshold.

(Initial forecast:) Little question that some form of additional aid is needed..  (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/07/states-in-fiscal-crisis-cuts-to-basic-services-loom-due-to-pandemic.html)  Watching Mitch + the Senate for a proposed dollar amount of any package. The House approved an additional nearly $1 trillion in state/local aid but Mitch didn't take it up before beginning a two-week July recess. A Moody Analytics report (in June) asserted that around $120 billion would be "...sufficient to get states through the 2021 fiscal year that starts next week." (https://www.pressherald.com/2020/06/24/report-state-local-aid-needed-to-avert-4-million-layoffs/) The ongoing, generally worsening U.S. outbreak may boost the urgency and perhaps the amount for any additional package.  However the relatively 'strong' June jobs report could have the GOP considering other stimulus measures (e.g., payroll tax cut) instead. (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/29/coronavirus-pelosi-and-schumer-urge-mcconnell-to-talk-stimulus-bill.html)

They did what they were told and look where many of these states are now.  I can hear this argument being made to McConnell and funding being allocated, but with strings and rules.

I think the chance is extremely high. The chance additional stimulus fails is low but greater than zero. And if that is possible, it is also possible that a limited stimulus without state/local help is passed. It really isn't far fetched. If GOP holds firm against too much stimulus now and loses the presidency (even without Senate control new legislation will pass one way or another), then Dems can quickly rush to pass giant packages in new term. If GOP holds firm against too much stimulus now and wins, GOP can pass giant packages- rewarding red states/states that came through in the general. Assigning a too low probability to this outcome (which can happen as a result of various scenarios- not just that aforementioned one) is a mistake. But I agree there is overwhelming pressure to pass one more round of meaningful stimulus where States also participate and the ask from the most populous states would easily surpass 100bln, with the other states demanding some proportionate-ish share to prove they are co-equal states- whether or not that's true from a per capita perspective.
